revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Johannes Welsch | image = | alt = | caption = | image_size = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1960|11|28|df=y}} | death_date = | origin = Saarlouis, Germany | instrument = Percussion | genre = [[Avant-garde music|Avant-garde]], [[Progressive metal|progressive]], [[Minimal music|minimalism]] | occupation = Percussionist, producer/audio engineer, educator | years_active = 1994 - present | label = Sonic Flame, Art Stew Records, [[Deep Listening]], NUUN Records | associated_acts = [[Hamid Drake]], [[:de:David Mott|David Mott]], [[Jesse Stewart]], [[Deep Listening Band]], [[Pauline Oliveros]], [[Malcolm Goldstein]] | website = }} '''Johannes Welsch''' is a German [[percussionist]], [[recording engineer]] and [[record producer|producer]] living in [[Canada]]. He is the son of German industrialist [[:de:Hans Welsch|Hans Welsch]] and, on his mother's side, the grandson of European statesman [[:de:Johannes Hoffmann|Johannes Hoffmann]].John Slof, "DSD Dillinger Stahlbau GmbH (A)", Case Study #0-390-033, DG-944-E, IESE International Graduate School of Management, Barcelona-Madrid, 1989. His professional approach to music production is based on his background as [[business school]] academic. He began his career teaching executive programs in [[Europe]] before entering the music industry in [[North America]]. A percussionist since the 1970s, he has been performing regularly with a large collection of gongs both as a solo performer or in collaboration with other artists since 1994."Bancroft percussion musician uses gongs." by Werner Bergen in ''The Examiner'', Peterborough, Ontario, March 30, 2007, p. B6. He is best known for his [http://deeplistening.org/site/content/bylabel Deep Listening Label] releases "Sound Creation" (2012) and "Dunrobin Sonic Gems" (2014). Welsch is the founder of the [http://sites.google.com/site/dunrobinsonicgym/ Dunrobin Sonic Gym], a center for the exploration, production and experience of sound and music in [[Ottawa]], Ontario, Canada."Gym Dandy" by Fateema Sayani in [http://www.ottawamagazine.com/tag/interiors-2012/ ''Ottawa Magazine''], February 2012, pp . 64-67."Exploring the Secret of Rhythm and Sound", Interview with Maike Dombrowski in [http://issuu.com/tonemagazine/docs/april2011/60 ''Tone Magazine''], April, 2011, pp. 60-61.
==Management & Management Education: 1990-2000== Upon studying economics at the [[University of Miami]] and management at [[IESE]], the University of Navarra's Graduate School of Management,See [http://www.ffi.org/?page=bestdissertation FFI Best Doctoral Dissertation Award], 1991. Welsch completed a post-doctorate year at [[International Institute for Management Development|IMD]] in [[Lausanne]], [[Switzerland]] in 1991. His writings in the early 1990s applied social systems analysis to organizational dynamics. Much of his work focused on family firms, then an emerging field of investigation. From 1991 to 1993 Welsch served as the Director of Postgraduate Studies at the Universitätsseminar der Wirtschaft (USW) at [[:de:Schloss Gracht|Gracht Castle]] near Cologne, Germany, where he taught executive programs. During the second half of the decade Welsch grew critical of management education and academia in general as evidenced by the publication "Reflections on Professional Cynicism in Education and the Management of Education Organisations“. From 1993 to 1997 he served on the Supervisory Board of DSD Dillinger Stahlbau GmbH in Germany. From 1996 to 1999 Welsch was an International Fellow at [[Johns Hopkins University]] in [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]].Sources for this time period include: * "Familienunternehmen auf der Schulbank." by Matthias Camenzind in [http://www.Handelszeitung.ch ''Handelszeitung''], Number 46, November 15, 1990, p. 18. * "L'Entreprise Familiale A L'Ecole." by Éric Meyer in [[:fr:L'Entrprise (magazine)|''L'Entreprise'']], Number 66, March 1991, p. 128. * "Heisse Kartoffel: Die Inflation der MBA-Programme." by Christian Kullmann in [http://www.capital.de ''Capital''], Number 10, October 1992, pp. 33-34. * "Sprungbrett fuer den Aufstieg in Spitzen-Positionen.", by Michaela Hoffmann in [http://www.vdi-nachrichten.com ''VDI Nachrichten''], November 20, 1992.Notable publications during this time period include: * [https://books.google.com/books?id=yrL0GgAACAAJ&dq=Johannes+Welsch&hl=en&sa=X&ei=s4daU-R-xODaBaP9gSg&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA "A Three Dimensional Conceptualization of Organizational Processes."] Research Paper # DI-175, IESE, University of Navarra, January 1990. * "A Strategy, Structure and Culture Based Approach to Human Resource Management." Research Paper # DI-204, IESE, University of Navarra, January 1991. * "Family Enterprises in the UK, Germany and Spain: a Transnational Comparison." [http://fbr.sagepub.com ''The Family Business Review''], Summer 1991, Volume IV, Number 2, pp. 191-204. * [https://books.google.com/books?id=TIliMgAACAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Johannes+Welsch%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=h5dpU_DRJsGZyASDyYDIBg&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBQ "''Ergebnisse einer explorativen empirischen Studie zum Stand der Personalarbeit in deutschen Unternehmen.''"], Research Paper # 4/1992, Universitätsseminar der Wirtschaft, Erftstadt, Germany, June 1992. * [https://books.google.com/books?id=Qf3FMgAACAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Johannes+Welsch%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hdNoU_WiGYOjyAT7hID4DQ&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAg „Empirical Evidence on the Familiarity and Adoption of Capital Budgeting Techniques in Small Firms of the Former GDR.“] with Ahmed Rahnema and Jon Slof, Research Paper # 5/1992, Universitätsseminar der Wirtschaft, Erftstadt, Germany, September 1992. * "The Impact of Family Ownership and Involvement on the Process of Management Succession." [http://fbr.sagepub.com ''The Family Business Review''], Volume VI, Number 1, Spring 1993, pp. 31-54. * "''Personalpolitik im Familienunternehmen.''" ''Personalwirtschaft'', October 1993, pp. 37-40. * "''Internationalisierung durch den MBA: Mythos oder Realität?''" in [[:de:Bärbel Schwertfeger|Bärbel Schwertfeger]], ''Das MBA Handbuch'', Düsseldorf: Econ Verlag, 1994, pp. 169-180. {{ISBN|3-430-18229-8}}. * "Reflections on Professional Cynicism in Education and the Management of Education Organisations: an Exploratory Approach." with Mirjam Southwell, [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/0965079950030307#.U2aJzMawgy4 ''Educational Action Research''], Volume 3, No. 3, 1995, pp. 337-345. * [http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/bpl/fabr/1997/00000010/00000003/art00007 "East Meets a West German Multinational Family Firm during Reunification and Transition."] [http://fbr.sagepub.com ''The Family Business Review''], Volume X, No. 3, Fall 1997, pp. 303-308.Sourced in part through personal profile information provided on [http://www.deeplistening.org/site/trustees Deep Listening Institute's "Board of Trustees" webpage]. ==Music Producer & Recording Engineer: 2001-Present== In 2000, while attending the [http://www.omegastudios.com Omega School of Applied Recording Arts & Sciences], Welsch built a low budget, professional recording studio in Fulton, MD with Scott O'Toole, who served as head engineer.The readers of [http://www.musicmonthly.com ''Music Monthly - Washington, Baltimore, and beyond''] awarded "The Chickencoop Digital Recording Studio, LLC" an honorable mention in the "Best Studio" category. ''Music Monthly'', February 2003, Vol. 20, No. 2, Issue #221, p. 29.''Baltimore Sounds: An Illustrated Encyclopedia of Baltimore Area Pop Musicians, Bands and Recordings 1950-2000'', compiled, written and edited by Joe Vaccarino, MJAM Press, Catonsville MD, 2012. The studio recorded hundreds of local and regional artists between 2001 and 2005, including [[The Track Record]] who were signed by [[Rushmore Records]] in 2005. In 2002 Welsch was appointed to the Omega School of Applied Recording Arts & Sciences' Curriculum Advisory Board. In 2005 Welsch moved to Canada where he founded the Dunrobin Sonic Gym which he has been managing since. Artists who have recorded and/or performed at the Dunrobin Sonic Gym include [[Hamid Drake]], [[:de:David Mott|David Mott]], [[Jesse Stewart]], [[Deep Listening Band]], [[Pauline Oliveros]], [[Glen Velez]], Lori Cotler, [[Malcolm Goldstein]] and [[Elaine Keillor]]. In 2012 Welsch was appointed to the [[Board of Trustees]] of [[Deep Listening Institute]]. ==Performing & Recording Artist: 1994-Present== ===Work with Gongs=== [[File:Gong Panorama at the Dunrobin Sonic Gym, July 11, 2008, small.jpg|thumb|Gong Panorama at the Dunrobin Sonic Gym]] Welsch has been recording and performing with a large collection of gongs since 1994. In approaching the gong he pays special attention to the instrument's dynamic range and frequency spectrum. He typically develops soundscapes which come out of and return to silence. While the amplitude increases the gong gradually unfolds its frequency spectrum, beginning with low frequencies (fundamental), and subsequently develops a wide array of overtones (harmonics). He prefers large acoustic spaces for his performances.Adapted from Welsch's commentary of the [http://www.drumsoloartist.com/cgi-bin/news/news.pl?record=38 "Cymbal Setup Of The Year"] on the online drummer collective www.DrumSoloArtist.com.Elaine Keillor quotes Welsch in her album liner notes. ===Sound Creation Album=== His album [http://www.deeplistening.org/site/content/sound-creation-johannes-welsch "Sound Creation"], an example of his solo performances, features the entire [http://www.drumsoloartist.com/Site/Cymbal_Setup.html "Sound Creation series of gongs"] made by [[Paiste]]. Released on the Deep Listening label in 2012 the album received a number of favorable reviews.Examples include: * Ed Pinsent in [http://www.thesoundprojector.com ''The Sound Projector Magazine''], April 10, 2012 * FdW in [http://modisti.com/12/2012/04/18/vital-weekly-827/#ixzz2SyxmJ2vR ''Vital Weekly''], # 827, April 18, 2012 * Julien Héraud in [http://www.improv-sphere.blogspot.ca ''improv sphere''], May 17, 2012 * Joseph Burnett in [http://www.dustedmagazine.com ''Dusted Magazine''], June 1, 2012 Music writer [http://jpburnett.com Joseph Burnett] notes about the production:
"''Using a series of differently-sized gongs, Johannes Welsch has created a deeply resonant piece of minimal drone, as profound and overwhelming as the best deep listening by his mentor Pauline Oliveros.''"[http://rateyourmusic.com/list/Phimister/obscure_alternatives__unsung_masterpieces_and_underappreciated_gems/3/ "Obscure alternatives, unsung masterpieces and underappreciated gems."], a compilation by Joseph Burnett published on ''www.RateYourMusic.com'', 2012.
The album credits include [[Anton Kwiatkowski]] (engineering), [[:de:Elaine Keillor|Elaine Keillor]] (liner notes), [[Louis Helbig]] (photography), and Scott O'Toole (mastering). ==Discographies== ===Selected Discography as Engineer/Producer=== * [http://movementunes.com/Nana_Frimpong/ "Seek and Find"] by Nana Frimpong (tlr-02-wo-010, 2002) * [http://radionothing.net/2003/november/noth1774.html "Communion"] by Johannes Welsch (tlr-03-wo-015, 2003) * [http://forums.stevehoffman.tv/threads/recommend-new-progressive-rock.266088/ "Sudden Cosmic Dissolution"] by SCD (Sonic Flame SOFL -10-01, 2010) * [http://www.nuun-records.com/albums/pauline-oliveros-jesse-stewart-the-dunrobin-session/ "The Dunrobin Sessions"] by Pauline Oliveros & Jesse Stewart (NUUN Records, 2012) * [http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/hamiddrakeandjessestewar "Timelines"] by Hamid Drake & Jesse Stewart (ARTSTEW Records ASR 001, 2013) * [http://zookeeper.stanford.edu/index.php?s=byAlbumKey&n=1045257&action=search&session= "Marking The Infinite"] by Norm Howard & Johannes Welsch (2013) * "Anagrams" by David Mott & Jesse Stewart (ARTSTEW Records ASR 002, 2014) * [http://www.paulineoliveros.us/store.html "Dunrobin Sonic Gems"] by [[Deep Listening Band]] & Special Guests (Deep Listening DL 47-2014) ===Selected Discography as Artist=== * [http://radionothing.net/2003/november/noth1774.html "Communion"] by Johannes Welsch (tlr-03-wo-015, 2003) * [http://www.prweb.com/releases/album/Stunderthorm/prweb546238.htm "Stunderthorm"] with David Hess and Paul Hinger (Sonic Flame SOFL-07-01, 2007) * [http://forums.stevehoffman.tv/threads/recommend-new-progressive-rock.266088/ "Sudden Cosmic Dissolution"] by SCD (Sonic Flame SOFL -10-01, 2010) * [http://www.csi.uottawa.ca/~bernard/rwac_schedule.html "Schizophonia"] with multi-instrumentalist John O'Connor aka [http://www.discogs.com/Johnny-Black-Punkantations/release/4384000 Johnny Black] (Sonic Flame SOFL-11-01, 2011) * [http://www.deeplistening.org/site/content/sound-creation-johannes-welsch "Sound Creation"] (Deep Listening DL 44-2012) * [http://zookeeper.stanford.edu/index.php?s=byAlbumKey&n=1045257&action=search&session= "Marking The Infinite"] by Norm Howard & Johannes Welsch (2013) * revision.text:
{{Infobox Governor |name= Jorge Sobisch |image= Jorge_Sobisch_in_2005.jpg |caption= |order= |office= Governor of Neuquén Province |term_start=1991–1995
1999–2003
2003 |term_end=2007 |vicegovernor= Federico Brollo (1991-95)
[[Jorge Sapag]] (1999-07) |predecessor= [[Pedro Salvatori]] (1991)
[[Felipe Sapag]] (1995) |successor=[[Felipe Sapag]] (1999)
[[Jorge Sapag]] (2007) |birth_date={{birth date and age|1943|1|16}} |birth_place= [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] |profession= graphic designer |party= [[Neuquén People's Movement]] |footnotes= }} '''Jorge Omar Sobisch''' (born January 16, 1943) is an [[Argentina|Argentine]] centre-right politician, formerly governor of [[Neuquén Province]]. He leads the [[Neuquén People's Movement]] and was a candidate for [[President of Argentina]] in 2007. ==Biography== Sobisch was born in [[Buenos Aires]] and moved to [[Neuquén, Argentina|Neuquén]] as a young boy with the military family of his father, [[Carlos Sobisch]]. He studied in Neuquén and Buenos Aires, then moved to [[Trelew]], [[Chubut Province|Chubut]] as a young man to work in a friend's design company. He became a graphics operator and [[typesetter]], later establishing his own company. He completed his military service in [[Sarmiento, Chubut]]. Sobisch assisted his [[Peronist]] father in founding the [[Neuquén People's Movement]] in 1961, following him into politics. The party won the Neuquén city elections in 1983 after the return of democracy and Sobisch became mayor, taking took a leading role in renewing the party. He also led the [[Independiente de Neuquén|Club Atlético Independiente]] [[football club]] from 1971. Sobisch was elected governor of the province in 1991, serving until 1995. He took over the leadership of the party in 1997. He won again as governor in 1999 and 2003, with 57% of the vote, his term expiring in 2007 when he stepped down. Sobisch led the founding of the Movement of the United Provinces, a new, conservative party, and was the movement's candidate for the Presidency in 2007. He had previously formed a centre-right alliance with [[Mauricio Macri]],[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/Archivo/nota.asp?nota_id=688802&aplicacion_id=12 ''La Nación'' {{es icon}}] although it did not survive Macri's alliance with [[Ricardo López Murphy]] (who is not on good terms with Sobisch); López Murphy was a conservative presidential candidate in both 2003 and 2007.[http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/1-62562-2006-02-04.html ''Página/12'' {{es icon}}][http://www.lanacion.com.ar/Archivo/nota.asp?nota_id=818595 ''La Nación'' {{es icon}}] [[File:Remerafuentealba.JPG|left|thumb|160px|A T-shirt commemorates the assassinated school teacher, Carlos Fuentealba.]] Sobisch is also seen as an ally of former [[Justicialist Party]] President [[Carlos Menem]] and had hoped to become the candidate of those Peronists opposed to President [[Néstor Kirchner]]. Following a scandal in his home province, concerning the April 7 death of local teachers' union member [[w:es:Carlos Fuentealba|Carlos Fuentealba]] (who was reportedly fired upon by provincial police during a protest despite being unarmed), Sobisch was largely shunned by disgruntled Peronists who mainly backed [[Alberto Rodríguez Saá]]. Sobisch was, however, backed by crime victims' rights activist [[Juan Carlos Blumberg]].[http://www.clarin.com/diario/2007/10/13/elpais/p-01518644.htm ''Clarín'' {{es icon}}] In 2007, Sobisch and his running mate, [[Jorge Asís]], gained 284,161 votes in the [[Argentine general election, 2007|presidential elections]], amounting to 1.56% of the national vote, in sixth place. His wife of 38 years, Liliana Planas, died on December 22, 2009, after falling from their ninth story Neuquén apartment building, in what local coroners determined to be a suicide.[http://www.clarin.com/diario/2009/12/22/um/m-02105990.htm ''Clarín'' {{es icon}}] ==External links== *[http://www.sobischpresidente.com/ Sobisch 2007 official site] (Spanish) *[http://www.clarin.com/diario/2006/01/30/elpais/p-00801.htm Interview], ''[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]'', 2001-01-30 (Spanish) *[http://www.neuquen.gov.ar/ Neuquen Province] (Spanish) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070611063335/http://www.mpn.org.ar/ Neuquino People's Movement] (Spanish) ==References== {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[Governor of Neuquén Province|Governor of Neuquén]]| before=[[Pedro Salvatori]] | after=[[Felipe Sapag]] | years=1991 – 1995}} {{succession box| title=[[Governor of Neuquén Province|Governor of Neuquén]]| before=[[Felipe Sapag]]| after=[[Jorge Sapag]] | years=1999 – 2007| }} {{s-end}} {{Commons category| Jorge Sobisch}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sobisch, Jorge}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Buenos Aires]] [[Category:Argentine people of German descent]] [[Category:Argentine people of Croatian descent]] [[Category:Argentine businesspeople]] [[Category:Governors of Neuquén Province]] [[Category:Mayors of places in Argentina]] [[Category:Candidates for President of Argentina]] [[Category:Neuquén People's Movement politicians]]

{{Infobox model | name = Malvika Subba | image = Malvika Subba montage photo.jpg | image_size = | caption = Malvika Subba during the beauty pageant of Mr and Miss Australia Nepal held in [[Sydney]]. | alt = Malvika Subba | birth_name = Malvika Subba ([[Limbu]]) | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1981|7|19|df=y}}{{cite web|title=Malvika Subba, Celebrity Nepal Profile|date=16 April 2013|accessdate=8 November 2017|url=http://celebritynepal.com/models/malvika-subba-profile}} | birth_place = [[Dharan, Nepal|Dharan]], [[Nepal]] | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | occupation = [[Model (person)|Model]], [[actress]], [[social activist]], [[Television presenter|television personality]], [[entrepreneur]] | yearsactive = 2002-present | height= {{height|m=1.68|precision=0}} | hair_color = Black | eye_color = Brown | agency = | spouse = Riyaj Shrestha | relatives = | website = [http://malvikasubba.com/ Malvikasubba.com] }} '''Malvika Subba''' ({{lang-ne|माल्बिका सुब्बा}}) is a [[People of Nepal|Nepalese]] [[media personality]], [[beauty queen]], [[actress]], [[television host]], [[social activist]] and [[entrepreneur]].http://malvikasubba.com/ About Malvika Subba She graduated from [[Pokhara University]] with Masters in Mass Communication and Journalism.[http://www.enasha.com/article.php?id=2223 Malvika Subba]. eNasha.com. Retrieved on 2016-12-19. ==Career== At the age of 21, Malvika was crowned as [[Miss Nepal 2002]], ever since then she has worked for Call Kantipur as TV host in [[Kantipur Television]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20140718083352/http://malvikasubba.com/malvika-subba-leaves-kantipur-television/ Malvika Leaves Call Kantipur]. malvikasubba.com In 2008, she worked for [[Voice of India]], [[MTV EXIT]] as the Ambassador for Human Trafficking[http://nepal.usaid.gov/newsroom/press-releases/press-releases-2010/227-mtv-exit-presents-road-to-exit-mtv-exit-live-in-nepal.html Nepal | U.S. Agency for International Development]. Nepal.usaid.gov (2016-04-25). Retrieved on 2016-12-19. Subba has also been associated with Youth SpokesPerson for Action Aid's Hunger Free Campaign,[https://web.archive.org/web/20100814155102/http://www.wavemag.com.np/issue/article3571.html ] HIV/AIDS Youth Leader by [[UNICEF]] and worked with Shangrila Housing as Sales and Marketing Manager in 2009–2011.[https://web.archive.org/web/20140221022040/http://www.fnw.com.np/cherry-on-top-malvika-subba/ ] In 2008, she has acted in movies and dramas like ''God Lives in The Himalayas'',[http://www.cybersansar.com/article.php?aid=2457 CS : CyberSansar.com - I play the protagonist's Mother : Malvika Subba]. CyberSansar.com (2008-04-29). Retrieved on 2016-12-19.{{cite web |url=http://isadoranepal.com/tag/malvika-subba/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-01-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007062811/http://isadoranepal.com/tag/malvika-subba/ |archivedate=2011-10-07 |df= }} ''Good Bye Kathmandu'' and ''Hamri Shiwani''. From April to October 2011, she worked as the chief editor for one of Nepal's leading fashion and lifestyle magazine, Navyaata.[http://navyaata.com/content/about-us Navyaata Magazine][https://web.archive.org/web/20110415010409/http://www.lexlimbu.com/2011/04/new-editor-of-navyaata-malvika-subba.html ] In 2011, Subba established her own retail clothing store with in-house designers. She is the Co-Founder and Creative Director of House of Alternative Apparel also known as HAA {{cite web |url=http://haanepal.com/about.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-01-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205172649/http://haanepal.com/about.html |archivedate=2012-02-05 |df= }} and Himalayan Climate Initiative (HCI). In 2015, she is the host and head judge of the third season of ''[[Mega Model]]''. ==Filmography== *[[Goodbye Kathmandu]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Malvika Subba}} * [http://malvikasubba.com/ Official Website] {{s-start}} {{S-ach}} {{succession box | before= Usha Khadgi
({{Flag|Nepal}}) | title= [[Miss Nepal]] [[World]] | years= 2002 | after= Priti Sitoula
({{Flag|Nepal}}) }} {{s-end}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Subba, Malvika}} [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Dharan]] [[Category:Miss Nepal winners]] [[Category:Nepalese female models]] [[Category:Nepalese actresses]] [[Category:Nepalese businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Kathmandu]] [[Category:Nepalese beauty pageant winners]] [[Category:Limbu people]] [[Category:Tribhuvan University alumni]] {{Nepal-bio-stub}} {{asia-pageant-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = McAvoy Brewing Company | logo = McAvoy Brewing Company.jpg | type = | foundation = [[Chicago, Illinois]], U.S. (1865) | founder = [[Henry V. Bemis]]
[[John H. McAvoy]] | defunct = 1920 | location_city = 23rd South Park Way,West Virginia History Journal Volume 19, Number 2 (January 1958), pp. 93 [[Chicago, Illinois]] | location_country = U.S. | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = [[John H. McAvoy]] | industry = [[Brewing]] | products = [[Beer]] | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | slogan = | homepage = }} '''McAvoy Brewing Company''' (founded in 1865 as '''Bemis & Rindge Brewery''' by Henry V. Bemis) was run by [[John H. McAvoy]] in [[Chicago, Illinois]] and was one of Chicago's largest breweries before Prohibition."His Labors Ended - John H. McAvoy passes the portals of eternity", Chicago Tribune July 25th, 1893 Coinciding with the [[Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Eighteenth Amendment]] going into effect on January 16, 1920, the brewery closed in 1920. ==History== [[File:Mcavoybrewery.jpg|thumb|McAvoy Brewery on 24th Street and South Park]] ===Early history=== In 1865, the brewery began in a three-story brick building close to the corner of [[Near South Side, Chicago|South Park Avenue and 23rd Street]] along [[Lake Michigan]]. In the early 1870s, a [[malt house]] was constructed next to the original building, along with 4 [[Ice house (building)|ice houses]] on the western side of the avenue in 1872, 1874, 1875, and 1876. In 1878 and 1879, two more ice houses were constructed on the east side of South Park Avenue. A substantial brick [[barn]] was built in 1878 and office building was built in 1879. In 1901, the company employed over one hundred men and the chief brewer was Fritz Hieronimus. Hieronimus learned the trade in [[Germany]] at [[Deutsches Brauereimuseum|Frankfort-on-the-Main]], a well known school for brewers at the time. In 1890, Hieronimus was elected as an honorary members of the [[Brewers Association|United States Brewmasters' Association]].{{cite web|title=District Philadelphia History Nov. 15, 1890 Western Brewer|url=http://www.mbaa.com/districts/Philadelphia/about/history/Pages/history1890WesternBrewer.aspx|website=mbaa.com|publisher=Master Brewers Association of Americas|accessdate=15 February 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160215001358/http://www.mbaa.com/districts/Philadelphia/about/history/Pages/history1890WesternBrewer.aspx|archivedate=15 February 2016|df=}} Until 1882, the officers of the company were:{{cite web|title=100 Years of Brewing, Western Brewer, August, 1901|url=https://chicagology.com/breweries/|website=chicagology.com|accessdate=15 February 2016}} *Austin J. Doyle, President *Adam Ortseifen, Vice President *H. T. Bellamy, Secretary and Treasurer Doyle was Chicago's former [[Chicago Police Department|Chief of Police]] and later became manager of the [[Illinois]] State [[Brewers Association|Brewers' Association]].{{cite news|last1=Kelley|first1=John|title=AUSTIN J. DOYLE, FORMER CHIEF OF POLICE DIES|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1924/02/08/page/10/article/austin-j-doyle-former-chief-of-police-dies|accessdate=15 February 2016|publisher=The Chicago Tribune|date=February 8, 1924}}[[File:Dahomey Village--On The Midway — Official Views Of The World's Columbian Exposition — 110.jpg|thumb|McAvoy Brewing Company located beside the Dahomy Village at Midway Plaisance during the World's Columbian Exposition, 1893]] ===McAvoy involvement=== From 1882 until 1920, [[John H. McAvoy]] was president of the company. McAvoy was the brother-in-law of Peter Leyendecker, who came from Germany in 1882 with his family to work with McAvoy. Leyendecker was the father of American illustrators [[J.C. Leyendecker]] and [[Frank X. Leyendecker]].{{cite news|last1=New York Times Staff|title=J.C. LEYENDECKER, NOTED ARTIST, 77|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1951/07/26/89455006.html?pageNumber=20|accessdate=15 February 2016|publisher=The New York Times|date=July 26, 1951}} In 1889, the McAvoy Brewery, along with the Wacker & Birk Brewery were sold to an English Syndicate, the Chicago Breweries Limited. After joining the syndicate, McAvoy continued to use the same name and management. McAvoy was instrumental and securing funding to return [[John Brown's Fort]] back to [[West Virginia]]Skilnik, Bob. ''Beer - A History of Brewing in Chicago''. Barricade Books, 2006, p. 56. after it had been brought to Chicago in 1892 for display at the [[World's Columbian Exposition]]. In 1893, in-house bottling was installed and McAvoy was among the largest breweries in Chicago. ===Prohibition=== As the [[Prohibition in the United States|Prohibition movement]] began, the cultural landscape changed and the business began a downturn. In 1920, the Brewery closed, which coincided with the [[Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Eighteenth Amendment]] going into effect on January 16, 1920. ==Timeline== *1862-64, Bemis & Rindge Brewery *1864-69, Downer, Bemis & Co. *1869-82, Downer & Bemis Brewing Co. *1882-87, Bemis & McAvoy Brewing Co. *1887-1920, McAvoy Brewing Co. == References == {{reflist|2}} [[Category:Beer brewing companies based in Illinois]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies based in Chicago]] [[Category:Defunct companies]]

{{Infobox scientist | image = Paul Bragiel - Image by Dan Taylor - dan(at)heisenbergmedia(dot)com.jpg | caption = Paul Bragiel at BDL Accelerate, Beirut, Lebanon, 21 November 2014. Image ©Dan Taylor/Heisenberg Media - http://www.heisenbergmedia.com/ | name = Paul Bragiel | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1977|9|15|df=y}} | residence = [[United States|U.S.]] | citizenship = [[United States|American]], [[Poland|Polish]], [[Colombia]]n | field = [[Computer Engineer]] and [[Business]] }} '''Paul Bragiel''' (born 15 September 1977 in [[Chicago, Illinois]]) is an internet entrepreneur and currently a managing partner of [[Bragiel Brothers]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/05/20/paul-bragiel-is-back-with-a-new-venture-firm/|title= Paul Bragiel is back with a new venture firm}}</ref>
==Early life== Bragiel, the oldest child of Mary and Walter Bragiel, was raised in [[Mt. Prospect]] and [[South Barrington, Illinois]]. In the late 1990s, he was involved in the [[demoscene]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://foundersweek.fi/paul-bragiel-is-the-startup-ambassador-of-silicon-valley/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-11-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130619010521/http://foundersweek.fi/paul-bragiel-is-the-startup-ambassador-of-silicon-valley/ |archivedate=2013-06-19 |df= }}</ref>
==Ventures== Bragiel graduated from [[University of Illinois]] in 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.linkedin.com/in/bragiel|title=Paul Bragiel - LinkedIn|publisher=}}</ref> Shortly after graduating he founded his first company, [[Paragon 5]], with offices in [[Chicago]] and [[Poland]]. In 2004, he founded the first location-based social network, [[Meetro]]. In 2008, he founded Lefora.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/product/lefora|title=Lefora - CrunchBase|publisher=}}</ref> which was sold to Crowdgather in the summer of 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/07/24/forum-site-lefora-gobbled-up-by-crowdgather/|title=Forum Site Lefora Gobbled Up By CrowdGather|first=Michael|last=Arrington|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2010, he launched i/o Ventures, a seed fund and accelerator based in San Francisco.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/01/06/io-ventures-incubator-san-francisco/|title=i/o Ventures – A Work/Cafe Incubator Launches In San Francisco|first=Michael|last=Arrington|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2012, he launched three more technology-focused seed funds. Savannah Fund ([[Sub-Saharan Africa]]) and Golden Gate Ventures ([[Southeast Asia]]) were created to foster entrepreneurship in those regions.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2011/11/15/bringing-silicon-valley-philosophies-overseas/ |title=Bringing Silicon Valley Philosophies Overseas |newspaper=WSJ}}</ref> Gamefounders ([[Eastern Europe]]) invests in companies building gaming-related products.{{cn|date=February 2018}}
In 2015, he launched Presence Capital, a $10m venture fund investing in early-stage [[Virtual Reality|virtual reality (VR)]] and [[Augmented Reality|augmented reality (AR)]] companies.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/12/10/new-venture-capital-fund-targets-vrar/77008868/ |title=New venture capital fund targets VR/AR |newspaper=USA Today}}</ref>
He travels around the world to give lectures on startups and is an advisor to governments on their technology and entrepreneurship policy including [[Philippines]], [[Singapore]], [[Brazil]] and [[Tanzania]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/digital/meet-silicon-valley-s-unofficial-emissary-world/149402|title=Meet Silicon Valley's Unofficial Emissary to the Rest of the World|publisher=}}</ref>
==Olympics== In 2013, Bragiel trained in [[cross country skiing]] in [[Finland]] with a view to competing in the 2014 [[Sochi Olympics]] under the [[Colombia]]n flag. In order to participate, Bragiel obtained Colombian citizenship by presidential decree and was soon globally addressed as the man who was hacking his way into the Olympics.<ref>[http://www.arcticstartup.com/2013/10/16/io-ventures-paul-bragiel-to-train-for-the-olympics-in-lapland i/o Ventures' Paul Bragiel to Train for the Olympics in Lapland: Today We are all #TeamPaul], ''Arctic Startup'', 13 October 2013</ref>
For the [[2016 Summer Olympics]], Bragiel joined the [[Tonga at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Tonga delegation]] as team [[attaché]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pina.com.fj/?p=pacnews&m=read&o=108341201457919b59f8bd549b33e5|title=Seven Tongan athletes bound for Rio Olympics|agency=Pacific Islands News Association|publisher=}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links == *[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703699204575017942678202222/ ''Wall Street Journal'' article about Bragiel's venture fund i/o Ventures]. *[https://techcrunch.com/2010/10/13/inside-io-ventures-tour-the-central-perk-for-code-tctv/ ''TechCrunch'' interview with Bragiel and Ashwin Navin, founding partners of i/o Ventures] *[https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2012/06/06/good-news-for-african-tech-silicon-valley-veterans-launch-10-million-seed-fund/ ''Forbes'' article on Savannah Fund] *[http://pandodaily.com/2012/12/18/golden-gate-ventures-looks-for-next-china-in-southeast-asia/ ''Pando Daily'' article on Golden Gate Ventures launch] *[https://online.wsj.com/news/article_email/SB10001424052702303497804579240112529250356-lMyQjAxMTAzMDAwNjEwNDYyWj/ ''Wall Street Journal'' article about Bragiel's Olympic quest] *[http://www.teampaul.com/ Bragiel's official fan page]

{{Infobox officeholder | image = Peter appel DOT.tif | pix = 25 | caption = Peter Appel in 2009 | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1964}} | birth_place = United States | residence = [[Alexandria, Virginia]] | nationality = [[United States|American]] | education = [[London School of Economics]]
[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]
[[Brandeis University]] | occupation = [[Management consultant]], [[Government official]] | office = [[Administrator of the Research and Innovative Technology Administration]] | term_start =2009 | term_end = 2011| appointed = [[Barack Obama]] | | subject = Business-related biographical | category = Business biography stubs | tempsort = | name = Peter H. Appel }} '''Peter H. Appel''' (born 1964) was the administrator of the [[Research and Innovative Technology Administration]] (RITA). From 2009 to 2011 Appel was the Obama Administration point person on transportation technology issues and research.[http://www.transportgooru.com/2009/04/president-obamas-nominees-for-usdot-administrations-fhwa-victor-mendez-rita-peter-appel/ President Obama’s nominees for US DOT administrations], Transport Gooru, April 3, 2009. He left RITA in late 2011 for the private sector to work on emerging technologies in the transportation industry.[http://www.traffictechnologytoday.com/news.php?NewsID=33436 Senior USDOT administrator, Peter Appel, leaves RITA], Traffic Technology Today, September 30, 2011. ==Biography== Mr. Appel has a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[economics]] and [[computer science]] from [[Brandeis University]] and a [[Master of Science]] degree in [[transportation]] from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]. He worked for the global management consulting firm of A.T. Kearney, Inc., where he led business improvement initiatives for clients in the private and public sectors, with a focus on Transportation and Infrastructure. Mr. Appel has worked in the transportation field since the late 1980s, and has supported organizations in the railroad, trucking, airline, and ocean shipping industries with growth strategy, supply chain improvement, post-merger integration, public-private partnerships, and other key business and policy issues. Previously, he served as the Special Assistant to the Administrator of the [[Federal Aviation Administration]], and as Assistant Director for Pricing and Yield Management at [[Amtrak]]. He was confirmed by the [[U.S. Senate]] as Administrator of the [[Research and Innovative Technology Administration]] (RITA) on April 29, 2009. During his tenure at RITA, Appel worked with Secretary [[Ray LaHood]] to advance key [[U.S. Department of Transportation]] (USDOT) initiatives by leveraging effective research and cross-modal coordination. These initiatives have included the Distracted Driving Summit, which brought key transportation researchers, advocates, decision makers and other leaders together to address this growing safety issue; the bolstering of USDOT Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) Program to best improve safety, efficiency, and environmental sustainability across all modes of surface transportation; and the establishment of the Department's Safety Council. Appel coordinated DOT's research programs associated with railroads, aviation, maritime transportation and vehicles. As administrator of RITA, he also coordinated DOT efforts on [[distracted driving]][http://www.jhsph.edu/erc/distracted-driving.html Symposium on Prevention of Occupationally-Related Distracted Driving], Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, April 18, 2011. and research gathering statistical data about the various transportation modes.{{cite web |url=http://www.rita.dot.gov/contacts/executive_profiles/appel.html |title=Peter H. Appel |date= |accessdate=2018-01-03 |quote= |publisher=[[Research and Innovative Technology Administration]] |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603211041/http://www.rita.dot.gov/contacts/executive_profiles/appel.html |archivedate=2009-06-03 |df= }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{USGovernment|sourceURL=[https://web.archive.org/web/20090603211041/http://www.rita.dot.gov/contacts/executive_profiles/appel.html]}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Appel, Peter H}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:United States Department of Transportation officials]] [[Category:Business intelligence]] [[Category:Alumni of the London School of Economics]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Brandeis University alumni]]

revision.text:
'''Raymond Pelgrims de Bigard''' (2 April 1875 to 14 May 1955) was a Belgian industrialist, famous for the conservation and restoration of historic castles.<ref>https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/dibe/persoon/6616</ref>
De Bigard became wealthy at the beginning of the 20th century. During the First World War, however, his activities were destroyed. He gained national fame in rescuing multiple important residences with his private fortune, personally owning multiple castles. In 1903 he bought Bijgaerden Castle, former residence of the [[Lord of Saventhem and Sterrebeke]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tuinencyclopedie.be/pages/detail.asp?Id=4393 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-11-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160323102657/http://tuinencyclopedie.be/pages/detail.asp?Id=4393 |archivedate=2016-03-23 |df= }}</ref> He restored the castle long before it became a protected monument in 1940.<ref>https://books.google.be/books?id=rKjn0nQrkzcC&pg=PA338&lpg=PA338&dq=Raymond+Pelgrims+de+Bigard&source=bl&ots=Ml1NIHvvFH&sig=E5M3-0tjZ3Gf6wVf60oXb2UPnOs&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwix_JW5v6_VAhWRKlAKHaiVAI0Q6AEIhgEwFQ#v=onepage&q=Raymond%20Pelgrims%20de%20Bigard&f=false</ref>
Besides [[Groot-Bijgaarden Castle]], he saved [[Beersel Castle]].
In 1934 he founded ''Les Demeures Historiques de Belgique''.<ref>http://anet.ua.ac.be/submit.phtml?UDses=67305290%3A775771&UDstate=1&UDmode=&UDaccess=&UDrou=%25Start:bopwexe&UDopac=isaarua&UDextra=au::107618</ref> For his efforts he received royal gratitude.
His son, [[Eugeen-Willy Pelgrims de Bigard]], inherited his castles.
==References== {{Reflist|35em}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
In [[international finance]], the '''redundancy problem''', also known as the '''n − 1 problem''', is a problem of inequality of the number of policy instruments and the number of targets at the international level,<ref>{{citation |author1=Ronald Winthrop Jones |author2=Peter B. Kenen | publisher = Elsevier | title = Handbook of International Economics, Volume 2 | year = 1984 | page = 1186 }}</ref> suggested by [[Robert Mundell]] in {{harvtxt|Robert Mundell|1969}}.<ref name = "Gandolfo 1995" /><ref>{{citation |author = [[Ronald McKinnon]] |page = 2 |volume = Working Paper No. 419 |location = |publisher = Stanford Center for International Development |title = Rehabilitating the Unloved Dollar Standard |url = https://siepr.stanford.edu/?q=system/files/shared/pubs/419_McKinnon.pdf |year = 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150527235627/https://siepr.stanford.edu/?q=system%2Ffiles%2Fshared%2Fpubs%2F419_McKinnon.pdf |archivedate = 2015-05-27 |df = }}</ref>
This problem does not occur at the one-country level.<ref name = "Gandolfo 1995">{{citation | author = Giancarlo Gandolfo | page = 227 | location = | publisher = Springer Science & Business Media | title = International Economics Two. | year = 1995}}.</ref>
Suppose the number of countries in the world is ''n''. Because this world is closed, one country's [[balance of payments]] surplus must be equal to another's deficit, and vice versa. Thus the sum of all countries' net payments positions must be zero. Therefore, if ''n'' − 1 countries out of ''n'' countries have determined their balances of payments, that of the ''n''th country is determined automatically.<ref name = "Alan 2002">{{citation | author = Alan Professor Winters | page = 397 | location = | publisher = Routledge | title = International Economics | year = 2002}}.</ref> This fact implies that, if all of the ''n'' countries have payments objectives, only ''n'' − 1 countries can achieve the payments objectives. In other words, all of the payments objectives can not be achieved simultaneously.
Similarly, if there are ''n'' [[currency|currencies]] in the world, only ''n'' − 1 [[exchange rate]]s can be "independent" because the exchange rate is a price of one money relative to another.<ref name = "Alan 2002" /> Other rates which are not independent are calculated as [[cross rate]].
There are only ''n'' − 1 countries to be determined, which implies the ''n'' th country is required to refrain from intervening its exchange rate. [[Benign neglect]] is one example for this fact.<ref>{{cite book|author=Ronald Winthrop Jones, Peter B. Kenen|title=Handbook of International Economics, Volume 2|url={{Google books|jpEV2Q13hA8C|Handbook of International Economics, Volume 2|page=PA1186|plainurl=yes}}|page=1186}}</ref><ref>{{citation |editor1=Maria Cristina Marcuzzo |editor2=Lawrence H. Officer |editor3=Annalisa Rosselli | page = 38 | volume = | location = | publisher = Routledge | title = Monetary Standards and Exchange Rates | year = 2002 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} *{{Cite journal|author=Robert Mundell|date=1969|title=The Redundancy problem and the World price level |journal = Monetary problems of International Economy|pages=379–382|publisher=Chicago university|editor=Robert Mundell and Alexender. K, and Swoboda.|ref=harv}}
[[Category:Financial economics]] [[Category:International economics]] [[Category:International finance]]

{{BLP sources|date=December 2010}} {{Infobox officeholder |image = Sadegh Mahsooli 01.jpg |image_size = |caption = |name = Sadegh Mahsouli |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|4|9}} |birth_place = [[Urmia]], [[Iran]] |nationality = [[Iran]]ian |title = [[Ministry of Welfare and Social Security (Iran)|Minister of Welfare and Social Security]] |term_start = 19 November 2009 |term_end = 3 August 2011 |president = [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] |predecessor = [[Abdolreza Mesri]] |successor = [[Reza Sheykholeslam]]
(Cooperatives, Labour and Social Welfare)
 |title2 = [[Ministry of Interior (Iran)|Minister of Interior]] |term_start2 = 24 December 2008 |term_end2 = 9 August 2009 |president2 = [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] |predecessor2 = [[Kamran Daneshjoo]] {{small|(acting)}} |successor2 = [[Mostafa Mohammad Najjar]] | alma_mater = [[Iran University of Science and Technology]] | party = [[Front of Islamic Revolution Stability]]{{cite web|url=http://eaworldview.com/2014/03/iran-political-threat-rouhani-introducing-endurance-front/|title=Iran: A Political Threat to Rouhani? Introducing the Endurance Front|publisher=EA WorldView|date=14 March 2014|access-date=1 March 2017}} | otherparty = [[Coalition of the Pleasant Scent of Servitude]][http://alef.ir/vdcdk90x.yt0k96a22y.html?25665 پایان حیات سیاسی جبهه متحد اصولگرایان] | net_worth = $160 million {{small|(2005)}} | allegiance = {{flagicon|Iran}} [[Iran]] | branch = [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps|Revolutionary Guards]] | serviceyears = | unit = | commands = 6th Special Division | battles = [[Iran–Iraq War]] }} '''Sadegh Mahsouli''' ({{lang-fa|صادق محصولی}}, born 9 March 1959) is an [[Iran]]ian politician who was [[Ministry of Interior (Iran)|Minister of Interior]] from 2008 to 2009 and [[Minister of Welfare and Social Security of Iran|Minister of Welfare and Social Security]] from 2009 to 2011. He was appointed to this post on 19 November 2009, as part of President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]]'s second cabinet after received vote of from [[Parliament of Iran|Parliament]]. From 24 March 2008 to 9 August 2009, he was [[Ministry of Interior (Iran)|Minister of Interior]] of Ahmadinejad's first [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]]. He was succeed [[Ali Kordan]] who was impeached by Parliament in November 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/topics/sadegh-mahsouli/ |title=Sadegh Mahsouli |author= |date= |work="Topics" |publisher=Washington Times |accessdate=2010-12-11}} Mahsouli withdrew his nomination once when the president nominated him for the position of oil minister in 2005 after admitted to [[Iranian parliament]] that he was worth $160 million.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/tehranbureau/2009/08/ahmadinejads-security-cabinet.html|title=Ahmadinejad's Security Cabinet|work=FRONTLINE - Tehran Bureau}} In 2011, it was announced that Ministry of Welfare will be merged with Ministry of Labour and Mahsouli will be leave cabinet after it.http://www.tabnak.ir/fa/news/163501/محرابیان،-محصولی-و-میرکاظمی-از-دولت-حذف-شدند/ Mahsouli was in charge of the Ministry of Interior when the alleged vote rigging happened in Iran's presidential election in June 2009. == June 13 Letter == On June 18, a letter was presented by Iranian filmmakers [[Marjane Satrapi]] (director of the critically Acclaimed Film [[Persepolis (film)|Persepolis]]) and has since been widely circulated with Mousavi Supporters. No verification of the letter has been provided. The letter was allegedly written by Interior Minister Sadegh Mahsouli to [[Ali Khamenei|Ayatollah Khamenei]] on June 13 (a day after the elections), states the fraud and lists the authentic vote count. A quick view on the letter shows that it was fake. The letter was roughly translated as follows; "''Salaam Aleikum.'' ''Following your concerns regarding the results of the presidential election and per your given discretion to have Dr. Mahmoud Ahmadinejad remain as president during this sensitive juncture. Therefore, everything has been planned in a way that the public announcement will be made in accordance with the interests of the regime and the revolution. All necessary precautions have been taken to deal with any unexpected events of election aftermath and the intense monitoring of all the parties' leaders as well as the election candidates.'' ''However, some believe that the real votes counted are as follows:'' ''Total number of votes: 43,026,078'' ''Mir Hossein Mousavi: 19,075,623'' ''Mehdi Karoubi: 13,387,104'' ''Mahmoud Ahmadinejad: 5,698,417'' ''Mohsen Rezaee: 3,754,218'' ''Void: 38,716'' ''Minister of Interior'' ''Sadegh Mahsouli''" {{Cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/does-letter-prove-iran-election-fraud/|title=Does Letter Prove Iran Election Fraud?|website=www.cbsnews.com|access-date=2016-05-03}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/Flash.aspx/166711|title=Claim: Letter Proves Vote Fraud in Iran - Latest News Briefs - Arutz Sheva|website=Arutz Sheva|access-date=2016-05-03}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/secret-letter-proves-mousavi-victory-says-report.aspx?pageID=438&n=secret-letter-proves-mousavi-victory-says-report|title=WORLD - Secret letter proves Mousavi victory, says report|website=www.hurriyetdailynews.com|access-date=2016-05-03}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/29/AR2009062900636.html|title=Iran's Guardian Council Affirms Vote Result|last=Erdbrink|first=Thomas|date=2009-06-30|last2=Branigin|first2=William|newspaper=The Washington Post|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|access-date=2016-05-03}}{{Cite web|url=http://ireport.cnn.com/docs/DOC-274079|title=Decent translation of interior minister's letter to supreme leader|website=CNN iReport|access-date=2016-05-03}} == References == {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box|before=[[Ali Kordan]]|title=[[Cabinet of Iran|Minister of Interior]]|years=2008-2009|after=[[Mostafa Mohammad-Najjar]]}} {{s-bef|before = [[Abdolreza Mesri]]}} {{s-ttl|title = [[Cabinet of Iran|Minister of Welfare and Social Security]] |years = 2009–2011}} {{s-aft|after = [[Reza Sheykholeslam]]|as=Minister of Cooperatives, Labour and Welfare}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-new}} {{s-ttl|title=Deputy Secretary-General of the [[Front of Islamic Revolution Stability]]|years=2016–present}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} {{Iran interior}} {{Ahmadinejad cabinet}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mahsouli, Sadegh}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Urmia]] [[Category:Iranian Azerbaijani businesspeople]] [[Category:Iranian billionaires]] [[Category:Iranian Azerbaijani politicians]] [[Category:Iranian businesspeople]] [[Category:Government ministers of Iran]] [[Category:Iranian Shia Muslims]] [[Category:Ethnic Azerbaijani Shia Muslims]] [[Category:Front of Islamic Revolution Stability politicians]] [[Category:Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps personnel of the Iran–Iraq War]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} '''Sakumzi Justice Macozoma''' (Saki) (born 1957) is a South African former political prisoner who is now one of South Africa's most prominent businessman and a leader in civil society.
==Early life and education== Macozoma was born in [[Port Elizabeth]] on 12 May 1957. He studied political science, economics and journalism at the [[University of South Africa]] (Unisa) and at Boston University in the USA. He holds a BA degree from Unisa.<ref name="bloomberg.com">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/markets/stocks|title=Stocks|website=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref>
==Political and business life== After spending five years in prison alongside Nelson Mandela on Robben Island for anti-apartheid activities he joined the [[South African Council of Churches]]. He also worked for the African National Congress (ANC) and South African Breweries. He became an ANC Member of Parliament in 1994 but left the legislature in 1996 to become managing director of Transnet Limited, South Africa's largest parastatal, that controls South Africa's rail network and harbours. During this time he was also chairman of South African Airways.<ref name="bloomberg.com"/>
Macozoma is one of a small group of former ANC politicians who left politics and rapidly became successful in the business world.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mg.co.za/articlePage.aspx?articleid=280442 |title=Anatomy of fast money |accessdate=2007-11-01 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120728222542/http://mg.co.za/articlePage.aspx?articleid=280442 |archivedate=28 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
He is chairman of Tshipi é Ntle Manganese Mining (Pty) Limited, international investment house,[[Safika Holdings]] and Ntsimbintle Mining BEE. Ntsimbintle Mining BEE, owned by a number of [[Black Economic Empowerment]] groups and Safika Resources Limited<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.safika.co.za/investments#safika-resources%7C|title=Investments - Safika Holdings (Pty) Ltd|work=Safika Holdings (Pty) Ltd|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en-US}}</ref> a 100% owned subsidiary of Safika Holdings Limited, have a 74% interest in Ntsimbintle Newco Mining that in turn own a 50.1% interest in Tshipi é Ntle Manganese Mining (Pty) Limited.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://investingnews.com/daily/resource-investing/critical-metals-investing/manganese-investing/south-africas-newest-manganese-mine-blasts-first-ore/|title=South Africa’s Newest Manganese Mine Blasts First Ore {{!}} Investing News Network|date=2012-11-01|work=Investing News Network|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en-US}}</ref> OM Holdings Limited, a Singapore based Australian Stock Exchange quoted company, own a 26% interest in Ntsimbintle Newco Mining. Jupiter Mining, a public unquoted Australian company, own 49.9% of Tshipi é Ntle Manganese Mining (Pty) Ltd. The Pallinghurst co-investors, composed of [[POSCO]], AMCI, Energy and Minerals Group, Pallinghurst Resources and [[Investec]] own 86.8% of Jupiter Mines Limited.<ref>http://www.jupitermines.com/images/jupiter---mumoo.pdf| page 4 of 19</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.safika.co.za/cgi-bin/safika/load.pl?saki |title=Former Managing Director of Transnet and former Chairman of STANLIB and Andisa Capital |accessdate=2007-03-26 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518184337/http://www.safika.co.za/cgi-bin/safika/load.pl?saki |archivedate=18 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Tshipi abandoned its sale of the company and will no longer IPO in South Africa as previously planned.<ref>https://www.metalbulletin.com/Article/3767389/NORTH-AMERICAN-MORNING-BRIEF-1611-Tshipi-mine-sale-cancelled-Lord-Copper-on-nickel-ferrous-scrap.html| Tshipi mine sale cancelled</ref> Jupiter Kalahari (Mauritius) Limited, 100% owned subsidiary of Jupiter Mining Limited, exited a joint venture agreement with OM Tshipi(s)PTE on 11th April 2017. The venture marketed all Manganese ore produced at the Tshipi Borwa Mine.<ref>http://www.jupitermines.com/images/jupiter---eiwohzaexu.pdf| page 3 of Jupiter Mines Limited's Annual Report 2017</ref> OM Tshipi(s)PTE will continue to market Manganese ore from Tshipi Borwa mine.
Macozoma is Deputy Chairman of Volkswagen South Africa, deputy chairman of Vodacom South Africa, Chairman of Credit Suisse Standard Security and Lliso Consulting. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/people/1713849-sakumzi-j-macozoma|title=Sakumzi Macozoma, Tshipi E Ntle Manganese Mining Pty Ltd: Profile & Biography|website=Bloomberg|language=en|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> From 2007 to December 2013, Macozoma was chairman of Liberty Holdings. He resigned<ref name="bdli_Libe">{{Cite web | title = Liberty chairman Saki Macozoma resigns | author = | work = Business Day Live | date = | accessdate = 2015-05-12 | url = http://www.bdlive.co.za/business/financial/2014/12/03/liberty-chairman-saki-macozoma-resigns | language = | quote = }}</ref> to concentrate on his Safika business interests.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.safika.co.za|title=Safika Holdings (Pty) Ltd|website=Safika Holdings (Pty) Ltd|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> Before joining Standard Bank he was chief executive of New Africa Investments Limited (Nail), a publicly listed investment company with a broad portfolio that included radio stations, outdoor media and the Hertz car rental company.
Macozoma is well known for his work in civil society and is a former chairman of the Council of Higher Education and former chairman of the University of Witwatersrand council. He is a member of the Board of Governors of [[Rhodes University]] and chairman of the Kwazulu–Natal Philharmonic Orchestra.<ref>kznphil.org.za/about-us/staff/</ref>
Mr. Macozoma has also served as president of Business Leadership South Africa and of the President's Big Business Working Group and formerly co-chairman of the Business Trust.
He was a member of the National Executive Committee of the [[African National Congress]] from 1991 to 2008.
In 2005 Billy Masethla, then director of South Africa's [[National Intelligence Agency (South Africa)|National Intelligence Agency]] (NIA), was arrested and charged with illegally conducting surveillance of Mr Macozoma and his family.<ref>ANC Daily News 22 11 2005</ref>
== Move to COPE ==
On 28 February 2009 Mr. Macozoma briefly joined [[Congress of the People (South African political party)|Congress of the People]](COPE), a party that broke away from the ruling African National Congress in 2008.<ref name="IOL2009">{{Cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/senior-anc-member-leaves-for-cope-1.436014#.Ukv2x1NmNr4|title=Senior ANC member leaves for COPE|accessdate=2013-10-02|publisher= Independent Newspapers (Pty) Limited|year=2009|author=Anon|work=Independent Online}}</ref> Mr Macozoma is now politically unaffiliated.
==Awards== In 2012 Macozoma and former president Nelson Mandela were together awarded the University of South Africa's (UNISA) highest honour, a Calabash award and received the university’s first Robben Island alumnus award, designed to honour those imprisoned by the apartheid regime because they fought against the system of State oppression.<ref name="UNISA2012">{{Cite web|url=http://www.unisa.ac.za/news/index.php/2012/10/honouring-stalwarts-and-developing-emerging-african-leaders/|title=Honouring emerging African leaders|accessdate=2013-10-02|publisher=University of South Africa|year=2012|author=Rivonia Naidu}}</ref>
The [[Anglican Church of Southern Africa]] honoured Macozoma when the [[Most Rev'd]] [[Thabo Makgoba]], [[Archbishop of Cape Town]] admitted him to the [[Order of Simon of Cyrene]] at a meeting of the church’s Provincial [[Synod]] in [[Benoni, Gauteng]] on 1 Oct 2013<ref name="ACSA2013">{{Cite web|url=http://anglicanchurchsa.org/view.asp?ItemID=541&tname=tblComponent1&oname=News&pg=front|title=Anglican Church gives award to Saki Macozoma|accessdate=2013-10-02|publisher=Office of the Anglican Archbishop of Cape Town|year=2013|author=Anon|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004221643/http://anglicanchurchsa.org/view.asp?ItemID=541&tname=tblComponent1&oname=News&pg=front|archivedate=4 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
